abstract_summ: These estimates differ markedly from those documented in countries such as Spain and Italy, in which COVID-19 case fatality rates exceed 8% (case of Italy) and from the percentage of patients who have required intensive care, which has ranged from 9% to 11% of patients in Mediterranean European countries.Here we show that it is possible to predict when the intensive care units will saturate, within a few days from the first cases of COVID-19 intensive care patients.The update for April 1, 2020, in Italy recorded 102,669 confirmed COVID-19 cases, with a median patient age of 63 years.In conclusion, a rapid adoption of ICP and regular audits of quality indicators for the management of COVID-19 patients might be important tools to improve the quality of care and outcomes.The novel coronavirus (COVID-19) began in China in early December 2019 and rapidly has spread to many countries around the globe, with the number of confirmed cases increasing every day.
title_summ: Are we different, like Europe?Coronavirus: Older Persons With Cancer in Italy in the COVID-19 PandemicCOVID-19 in Brazil: advantages of a socialized unified health system and preparation to contain casesThe Exponential Phase of the Covid-19 Pandemic in Central Italy: An Integrated Care PathwayDescription of Covid-19 Cases in Brazil and ItalyManagement of COVID-19 Outbreak in Argentina: The BeginningCOVID‐19 in Spain: Transplantation in the midst of the pandemicCOVID-19 Epidemic in the Middle Province of Northern Italy:World governments should protect their population from COVID-19 pandemic using Italy and Lombardy as precursorCOVID-19 Outbreak in Italy: Protecting Worker Health and the Response of the Italian Industrial Hygienists AssociationCOVID-19 and Italy: what next?COVID-19 in Colombia endpoints.Impact, Logistics, and Strategy in the First Line Hospital100 Days of COVID-19 Prevention and Control in ChinaEffect of COVID-19 on liver transplantation in KOREA.Heterogeneity of COVID-19 outbreak in Italy.
title_abstract_phrases: These estimates differ markedly from those documented in countries such as Spain and Italy, in which COVID-19 case fatality rates exceed 8% (case of Italy) and from the percentage of patients who have required intensive care, which has ranged from 9% to 11% of patients in Mediterranean European countries.Here we show that it is possible to predict when the intensive care units will saturate, within a few days from the first cases of COVID-19 intensive care patients.In conclusion, a rapid adoption of ICP and regular audits of quality indicators for the management of COVID-19 patients might be important tools to improve the quality of care and outcomes.COVID-19 Epidemic in the Middle Province of Northern Italy: Impact, Logistics, and Strategy in the First Line HospitalThe novel coronavirus (COVID-19) began in China in early December 2019 and rapidly has spread to many countries around the globe, with the number of confirmed cases increasing every day.The update for April 1, 2020, in Italy recorded 102,669 confirmed COVID-19 cases, with a median patient age of 63 years.
